I install the JDK in wherever the installer or package manager puts it
by default, and set up environment variables (esp. the PATH, but also
JAVA_HOME and JDK_HOME) to refer to the install directory, if the
installer or package manager has not set them up already.

For JUnit and other Java libraries, I put them in a lib/ subdirectory
of my project's versioned source tree, so that I can just check out
the project and build it without any further fiddling about.

--Nat

2008/5/10 ben.aurel <ben.aurel@...>:
> hi
>
> I have some another basic questions on my quest for a "professional"
> java environment with JUnit...
>
> I'm working on Mac OS X and I try to find out how experiences java
> folks organize their Java development environment. It breaks down to
> the following 4 questions:
>
> 1. Basic JDK Installation
> --------------------------
> After downloading the jdk.zip file from SUN, where do you put those
> contents?
> WIN: C:\jse5, (others ?)
> MAC: standard install path is /Library/Java/Home
> (do the mac guys leave it this way, or are there arguments against
> that path?)
> NIX: ?
>
> 2. Java Libraries like JUnit
> ----------------------------
> where to put 3rd party libraries?
>
> WIN: ?
> MAC: /Developer/Java, ~/Library/Java/, ... ?
> NIX: ?
>
> 3. Environment Settings for JUnit in .bash_profile
> --------------------------------------------------
>
> I think this is the right way to do it:
>
> export JUNIT_HOME="/Developer/jlibs/junit"
> PATH=$PATH:$JYTHON_HOME:$JUNIT_HOME
>
> export CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:$JUNIT_HOME/junit-4.4.jar:$JUNIT_HOME
>
> but why do I need
> $JUNIT_HOME/junit-4.4.jar
> and
> $JUNIT_HOME
> in the classpath?
>
> 4. wrapper for running junit
> ------------------------------
>
> is there no better way to run junit then with commands like
>
> $ java org.junit.runner.JUnitCore ...
>
> do you write command wrappers and how?
>
> thanks a lot for your answers
>
> Ben
